generated.forum_summary:
Title: Can space debris actually block access to outer space?

Nearly 15,000 tons of debris orbit Earth. With launch rates accelerating, Kessler syndrome looks increasingly plausible. But would even severe debris buildup actually lock humanity out of the cosmos?

I looked at two scenarios: accidental runaway cascades, and deliberate dispersal by a bad actor trying to monopolise space.

The surprising finding: even fairly pessimistic accidental Kessler scenarios only raise launch costs by ~30%. A rocket spends *minutes* passing through LEO; satellites spend *years* there. That's why the highway analogy works — running across a fast but sparse road is vastly safer than driving along it.

Deliberate dispersal is more concerning. Tens of thousands of tons of optimally-sized debris (~1mm particles) *could* make launches prohibitively expensive. The cost to deploy such debris is already within reach of major actors, and falling fast.

But several factors cut the other way:
- Shielding scales favourably — Whipple shields can handle worst-case fragments
- Inspection regimes are feasible — hard to secretly launch thousands of tons of sand
- Sealing the sky is slow — giving time for international response
- Rocket size helps — larger rockets have lower surface-area-to-volume ratios

My bottom line: access to orbit is more resilient than it might seem. The real concern isn't blocking transit to outer space, but the diffuse damage to satellite infrastructure that even moderate debris increases could cause — especially for reconnaissance and arms-control verification.

pub-002.title: No Easy Eutopia: Why Great Futures Are Hard to Achieve

decisions.forum_title: No Easy Eutopia: Why Great Futures Are Hard to Achieve
decisions.social_title: Why might a world of abundance still be a moral catastrophe?

generated.abstract:
A future of abundance, freedom, and universal happiness could still be a moral catastrophe.

Even if humanity survives and flourishes by most measures, we could squander almost all of our potential. The problem: the value of the future depends on getting many independent factors right simultaneously—from population ethics to the treatment of digital minds. A single error can undermine most achievable value, and history suggests such errors are the norm.

This essay argues that "eutopia" is a narrow target, not a big one. Most plausible moral views turn out to be "fussy" about what counts as a near-best future. Material abundance won't get us there by default. Reaching a truly great future will require deliberate, sustained effort to hit a target that's surprisingly small.
